name: AWS Database Service Overview
description: Covers AWS purpose-built databases for various application needs.

cards.front: Your app needs fast key-based access to millions of shopping cart entries per second. Which AWS database service is purpose-built for this use case?
cards.back: Amazon DynamoDB is designed for high-throughput, key-value access with single-digit millisecond performance.
cards.example: An e-commerce site stores customer shopping carts in DynamoDB for fast read/write during flash sales.
cards.subject: AWS Database Service

cards.front: A social media platform needs to analyze complex relationships like user follows, likes, and recommendations. Which AWS database should you use?
cards.back: Amazon Neptune is the graph database service designed for handling relationship-based queries efficiently.
cards.example: A professional networking platform uses Amazon Neptune to suggest new connections based on mutual links.
cards.subject: AWS Database Service

cards.front: You're building an industrial IoT solution that logs temperature data every second from thousands of sensors. Which AWS database service is optimized for this pattern?
cards.back: Amazon Timestream is optimized for time series data, making it ideal for telemetry and IoT workloads.
cards.example: A factory monitors equipment health metrics using Amazon Timestream for historical trend analysis.
cards.subject: AWS Database Service

cards.front: Your DevOps team wants to cache frequently accessed API responses to improve performance. Which in-memory AWS database service should they use?
cards.back: Amazon ElastiCache for Redis is a fully managed in-memory data store ideal for caching and real-time analytics.
cards.example: An API gateway caches user authentication tokens in ElastiCache Redis to reduce database load.
cards.subject: AWS Database Service

cards.front: Your compliance department needs a cryptographically verifiable record of banking transactions. Which AWS database service should you choose?
cards.back: Amazon QLDB is a ledger database that provides an immutable, cryptographically verifiable transaction log.
cards.example: A fintech app logs every customer transaction in Amazon QLDB to support regulatory audits.
cards.subject: AWS Database Service
